notes:
1. Concept

Limit systems are used in engineering drawings to define the acceptable range of variation for the dimensions of a manufactured part. This ensures that parts are interchangeable and will fit together as intended.

2. Key Terminology

  • Basic Size: The theoretical, exact size from which limits of size are derived. It is the size shown on the drawing (e.g., 25 mm).
  • Actual Size: The size of the finished part as measured.
  • Limits of Size: The maximum and minimum permissible sizes for a feature.
    • Maximum Limit of Size: The largest acceptable size.
    • Minimum Limit of Size: The smallest acceptable size.
  • Tolerance: The total amount a specific dimension is permitted to vary. It is the difference between the maximum and minimum limits of size. Tolerance is always a positive value.
  • Deviation: The algebraic difference between a size (actual, max, or min) and the corresponding basic size.
    • Upper Deviation: Maximum Limit - Basic Size.
    • Lower Deviation: Minimum Limit - Basic Size.
  • Allowance: The intentional difference between the maximum material conditions of mating parts. It is the minimum clearance (for clearance fits) or maximum interference (for interference fits).

solvedExamples.question: A shaft has a specified dimension of $50 \pm 0.05$ mm. What is the tolerance for this dimension?
solvedExamples.explanation: The maximum limit of size is $50 + 0.05 = 50.05$ mm. The minimum limit of size is $50 - 0.05 = 49.95$ mm. The tolerance is the difference between the maximum and minimum limits: $50.05 - 49.95 = 0.10$ mm.

solvedExamples.question: For the shaft dimension of $50 \pm 0.05$ mm, what is the basic size?
solvedExamples.explanation: The basic size is the nominal dimension from which the variations are specified. In this case, it is 50.00 mm.
